Dr. Hamilton Wright Mabie, associate editor of The Outlook and
close personal friend of Theodore
Roosevelt, will deliver a lecture on
"Our Neighbors, the Japanese" in
McCoy Hall at 5 o'clock Tuesday.
Dr. Mabie began the first of his
two lecture tours last Saturday. He
will make addresses on the Japanese
before universities, legislatures,
chambers of commerce, boards of
trade and other organizations in Baltimore, Athens, Ga.; Montgomery,
New Orleans, Jackson, Cleveland,
Detroit and Buffalo. His second
tour, beginning April 8, will include
Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Louis,
Kansas City, Omaha and Oklahoma
City. The arrangements have been
made by the American Association
for International Conciliation.
Dr. Mabie spent the summer of
1913 in Japan lecturing in the universities on "American Ideals,Character and Life." His object was to
interpret America to the Japanese,
Just as, during the previous year,
Dr. Nitobe had interpreted Japan
to Americans. Dr.Mabie was upusually well received and the lectures
were reported to be tremendous
successes. The Imperial University
of Tokyo found it impossible to
meet satisfactorily the demands for
tickets of admission to his lectures.
Tributes to his popularity were
given by the Emperor, the President of the House of Peers, the
Mayor of Tokyo and others.
More than this, it has often been
said that Dr. Mabie rendered conspicuous services in the interest of
good mutual_ understanding between
the United States and Japan. Most
of his eighty lectures were given to
students, who, in that country, are
a most important factor in molding
public opinion. His elucidations of
American institutions and character
Were published widely in Japan.
His accounts of Japanese life, customs and ideals should be no less
interesting and valuable to Americans.

By carrying off the honors at the
Georgetown games on March 7, the
track team made a triumphant finish
to a successful indoor season. In
every meet in which it has competed
the team has won honors, and the
unbroken succession of victories
makes prospects unusually bright
for the more important outdoor season, which will begin immediately
after the Easter recess. The squad
has shown excellent spirit during
the indoor season, and the men have
stuck to their work, almost without an exception.

In both these meets several cage
records, some of long standing,
were smashed.
These preliminary contests put
the men in first-class condition for
the big event of the indoor season
—the Armory meet. In these
games, in which athletes from the
classiest squads in the East took
part, Hopkins devoted its strength
to putting three relay teams on the
floor; all of which were victorious.
The first team defeated Virginia,
the second took the honors from
Catholic University and the Maryland Aggies, and the freshman team
ran away from the freshmen of
Georgetown.
The following week the first relay team went to the Meadowbrook
Athletie Club games in Philadelphia,
where it defeated a team from Lehigh by a large margin. Finally,
in the Georgetown meet, the team
piled up a total of thirty-six points,
taking' first place in the collegiate
class.

SENIORS WIN INTERCLASS DEBATE
Victorious Over Juniors in Annual Contest—Monroe Doctrine the Issue.
Tingley Best Soph Orator.

Nineteen fourteen won the annual
interclass debate Friday night in
McCoy Hall. The class won from
the seniors of last year, and the
victory last week gives it the honor
of being the first class in many
years to win two successive debates.
The senior team, composed of
Malcolm Lauchheimer, •Steuart D.
White, Carl J. Weber, "Alec" Barton, alternate, and Albert L. Hammond, adviser, argued the negative
of "Resolved, That the Political
Interests of the United States Demand the Abandonment of the
Monroe Doctrine."
President-emeritus Remsen, Rev.
Dr. Charles Fiske and Joseph T.
Singewald, the judges of debate,
were unanimous in their decision
favoring the seniors. The junior
affirmative team consisted of Joseph
T. Bartlett, Jr., Millard Eiseman,
C. Sewell Weech, Avra Warren,
alternate, and F. Courtney Tarr,
adviser. Dr. John C. French presided.
From the standpoint of subject
matter, neither team gave evidences
of having delved deeply into the
rich fields of opinion available on
such an issue as the Monroe Doctrine. The seniors argued for continuance of the policy because, they
said, it was "necessary." The
juniors said it was "unnecessary,"
and so the debate went on. It developed, however, that the reasons
backing the senior claim were somewhat more clearly defined, and their
side of the question was more easily
defended because of the fact that
dramatic opposition to the Monroe
Doctrine is not possible, and the
decision properly went to '14.
The most finished presentation
during the debate was made by
"Joe" Bartlett, the first speaker for
the junior team. Carl Weber was
the most convincing of the seniors.
Thomas J. Tingley won the
Adams Medal for sophomore public speaking. He recited Robert
Ingersoll's dramatic nomination of
James G. Blaine for the Presidency,
which was the oratorical feature of
the Republican National Convention of 1876. The other speakers
were Samuel L. Leitheiser and L.
Clarence Cohn. The judges of the
contest were Prof. John H. Latane
and Wilfred P. Mustard and Dr.
David E. Wegelein.
Musical numbers were furnished
by the Instrumental Club, and four
picked "artists" from the Glee Club.

MUSICIANS AT THE PHIPPS CLINIC

DAVIS WINS CHESS TOURNAMENT

Glee and Instrumental Clubs Sing and
Play for Sick—Are Well Received.
Many Regular Men Absent.

"Cigar King" Finished With an Average
of .818—Melamet and Nachlas
Were Second and Third.

The combined Musical Clubs
gave a concert at the Phipps Cl:nic
on Tuesday, but there was a wholesale absence of singers and players,
making the affair somewhat disappointing to those who had journeyed over to Broadway to entertain the sick. The clubs, however,
were very well received and frequent encores were called for.
The Glee Club was unfortunately
unbalanced. There were plenty of
bass singers, but only one first and
two second tenors. The deepthroated men were thus compelled
to work the "soft pedal," and the
effect was said to be rather pleasing.
Some important- changes will
probably be made in the plan of
the schedule next year. Instead of
giving the more important concerts
and making all the trips in the early
part of the season and allowing the
organization to fall to pieces toward
the end of the season, the less important concerts will most likely be
arranged for the fall next year and
the heavier work done after Christmas. In this way it is hoped that
the spirit and enthusiasm will keep
up until the last concert has been
given.

Four women are among the six
students who stand highest in the
graduating class of the Hopkins
Medical School, according to Dr.
Franklin P. Mall, professor of
anatomy, who made the statement
to refute a charge that the feminist
movement was "biological bosh."
Prof. William T. Sedgwick of the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in a published article, said
recently that "biological bosh" was
the only term applicable to the action of women in forcing themselves to the front in every line of
endeavor. The article aroused the
ire of suffragists and also the interest of Dr. Mill.
Dr. Mall wrote a letter to Professor Sedgwick, in which he told
of the fine work of the women students in the fourth-year class of
the Medical- School. Everyone is
now interested to know just who
these women leaders are, but Dr.
J. Whitridge Williams, dean of the
school, is unwilling to give the
names at the present time. "To do
so," he said, "would not be proper,
since the averages of the students
will not be finally determined until
June, and it is possible that those
who stand at the head now may fall
back in their averages before Commencement Day."
The observation of Dr. Mall is
all the more interesting, inasmuch
as there are eleven women in the
class and eighty men.
Dr. Williams did say, however,
that five of the eleven women in the
fourth-year class were in the first
third of the class and in line for the
appointments to interneships in the
Hopkins Hospital. Two of these
young women are Baltimoreans.
They are Miss Alma Rothholz and
Miss Mabel Belt. Both were
graduated in the Class of 'o6 of the
Western High School. Miss Belt
subsequently took her bachelor's degree from Goucher College and
Miss Rothholz from Smith.

Engineering Advisory Committee Meets

A discussion of the first formal
announcement of the Department of
Engineering occupied the greater
part of the time at the meeting of
the advisory committee of that department last Wednesday.
A circular, which is to be issued
soon, will contain announcements of
the full teaching staff enrolled, information concerning the engineering scholarships and, most important of all, a full description of the
required and elective courses offered in the three branches of engineering. '
Routine work took up the remainder of the meeting.
Cheer up, flunkee, you'll get by
eventually. Consider the number of
mere test tubes that are graduated.
—Princeton Tiger.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 16, 1914.

THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to express its regret at the loss of R.
Webb - Peploe from its editorial
staff. Mr. Webb-Peploe has resigned from the University.
A New Rule for Freshmen.
An alumnus now holding a position with one of the large corporation in this city, in a letter to THE
NEWS - LETTER, proposes, among
other rules, that freshmen attendance at all organization meetings
of the University's activities, be
made compulsory. The suggestion
appeals at once, because of its
soundness and necessity.
It comes, too, just at a time when
the Student Council is formulating
a "Code of Freshman Regulations,"
and THE NEws - LETTER believes
that it should be made into a rule.
The men at the helm of the University's activities know how trying
it is to persuade first-year men to
become interested in some one of
the activities. To get a large attendance at the organization meetings requires a personal canvass;
and then, frequently, the results are
disappointing. Such a state of affairs should not exist. It is not
right that the leaders should "drum
up trade" among freshmen. The
new men should be made to realize
at the outset that they are not only
wanted, but urged to show an active
interest in the affairs of the college.
They will not realize this, however, unless it is brought before
them emphatically or even forcibly.
This, obviously, is not the duty of
the leaders of the specific activity;
it is the duty of the Student Council.
Then, again, a large freshman interest is necessary to maintain the
traditions of the University—espe-

cially is this true at this era of expansion. If the University is to
grow, its activities should become
tfk
fainumns
11111111111ho
correspondingly greater. The in=
creased number of new men makes
it evident that the old order must
be changed. The days when the
undergraduate body was just a "big
family" are passing. The leaders
can no longer reach every individual
for a "little talk on football." This
was apparent this year, with the
result that a great many of the new

men are without some "hobby"

IN FAVOR OF "BILLY" SUNDAY
Hopkins Ministers Almost Unanimous in
Wish to Get "Vaudeville Evangelist" for Baltimore Campaign.

Among the students in the University are a half dozen of ministers
who are taking an active part in the
discussion over the advisability of
securing "Billy" Sunday, the evangelist, for a Baltimore revival.
One of them who had a knife and
fork in the Emerson Lunch when
the subject was first discussed by
the Ministerial Union, confided the
following to a reporter for THE
NEws - LETTER during a physics
quizz:
"You won't tell anyone or make
fun of me, will you ?"
"Oh, no; of course not."
"Very well, then. I do certainly
want Mr. Sunday to come here. I
believe in muscularity, as you well
know, and I am very anxious to let
him get a chance at the Baltimore
sinners."
The following deposition is the
only one of dissent:
"I am opposed to going to the
theatre. They say Mr. Sunday is a
vaudeville performer, so I don't
think he'll fit in with my policies.
See!"

Yale's Football Trouble.

Yales real football trouble has
been oddly pointed out by Captain
Talbott's recent plea that the
coaches be barred from the sidelines and the quarterback be allowed
to run his game the way he wants.
Among the great colleges he stands
almost alone.
The answer to his attitude and to
the Yale football defeats is that
Yale has received to much coaching. In the West it has always
looked as though the multiplicity of
coaches at Yale should bring great
results. As a matter of fact, it has
brought ruin.
Last season there were six different offensive coaches, each with
his own theory of play. Shevlin
was perhaps the most prominent.
He boasts a distinct following that
believes in him utterly, but the
others were not far behind. As a
result, Yale was taught six different
theories of play and naturally could
not work any of them. In the Colgate game, where Yale suffered defeat, the eleven, bewildered by varying instructions, quit in despair. If
the quarterback had been left alone,
he might have saved the day by deciding for himself definitely on
something. Hence Yale wants him
left alone.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 16, 1914.

NEW LACROSSE MEN PROMISING
A Galaxy of Former City College Players
and Raw Material Pleases Coaches.
Outdoor Practice This Week.

With the first game of the season
less than two weeks off, and the
first outdoor practice to take place
in a few days, the lacrosse squad is
just entering upon the hardest work
of the season.
As has been the custom for a
number of years, the alumni twelve
will be met in the first game, which
is scheduled for March 28. Coach
Raney Wolfe, assistant coaches Eddie Hulburt and Bob Lowndes, the
Schmeisser brothers and many other
former stars will be in the line-up
for the alumni.
The squad finished its indoor practice last week and on Wednesday.
Captain "Butts" Sutton will have all
the candidates for the team report
at Homewood for the first line-up
practice of the season.
The coaches are pleased with the
improvement made by the new players. Four of them—Kaiser, Brooks,
Baxley and Fulton — are fighting
for positions on the defense, and a.1
will be given trials in the early
games before any definite selections
are made. Stuart and Bartlett are
improving as candidates for the
goal position. On the attack, Prince
and Nelson have, by hard work,
forged rapidly to the front and will
probably be given a chance to make
good in one or more of the games.
Paul Sutton and Frank will make
good "bench-warming candidates,"
ready to be used in any exigency.
Leibensperger, gridiron star, who
was a member of the lacrosse squad
last year, will start practice on
Wednesday. He has been excused
from cage practices because of his
inability to see the ball there.
All efforts from now on will be
devoted to the development of
team-work, which, so far, is lacking. "As a collection of about thirty
individual lacrosse players, some
good and some fair, the squad looks
excellent; but as a lacrosse team,
thus far, there is none," is the
opinion of an old player who
watched practice last week.
W. and L. Solves High Cost of Living.

Washington and Lee's athletes
have discovered a new way to get
the better of Mr. High Cost of Living. Good board here is quoted at
about"six dollars a week, but students who are taken ill can be
housed at the hospital indefinitely
for two dollars—not a week, but
per annum.
The mumps have been floating
around Lexington and they first got
to Caminero, one of the basketballers, who had to go to the hospital and stay there for some time.
He was later joined by Jim Somerville, the discus thrower; Kit Carson, the pitcher, and several other
athletes. Richard W. Fowlkes, assistant manager of the basketball
team, is getting pneumonia in order
to qualify for admittance to the infirmary.

football last year and about $10,003
in baseball. The track team lost

walks for the formal gymnasium
exercise now required of the students.
* * *
The University of Nebraska faculty has displaced baseball as a college sport, on account of the uncertainty of the rules governing summer ball.

Leading college rowing coaches
are united in the opinion that the
four-mile race is injurious to the
participants, and that they suffer in
later years as a result of overdevelopment.

had their annual dinners On the

in favor of placing a knowledge of
swimming among the requisites for
the bachelor of arts degree. It is
one of the requirements for graduation at Princeton.

The regular lectures of Dr.
Charles Francis Adams'course came
to an end last Thursday, when the
noted Bostonian talked of the effect
which Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation had upon the English policy during the Civil War.
The feeling in England up to
the time of the proclamation had
been decidedly in the South's favor,
and the British Ministry was on the
point of recognizing the Confederacy as a nation. However, the element of slavery, which was brought
forward to a prominent position by
Lincoln's act, turned the tide against
the South. While slavery was not
a great factor in causing the struggle, and while the North was not
fighting with an eye to stamping it
out, the impression got abroad in
England that this was the case, and
the lower classes especially took a
firm stand against the recognition
of the Southern States.
Dr. Welch announced before the
lecture that Dr. Adams would give
two extra talks, on Thursdays,
March 19 and 26, upon his "Opinions and Theories of the Experiences, Career and Character of Gen.
Robert E. Lee." Lee is said to be
a favorite character of Dr. Adams.
His studies of.the great Virginian
are ranked among the most valuable contributions to his biography.

Dr. Hamilton Wright Mabie, associate editor of The Outlook and
close personal friend of Theodore
Roosevelt, will deliver a lecture on
"Our Neighbors, the Japanese" in
McCoy Hall at 5 o'clock Tuesday.
Dr. Mabie began the first of his
two lecture tours last Saturday. He
will make addresses on the Japanese
before universities, legislatures,
chambers of commerce, boards of
trade and other organizations in Baltimore, Athens, Ga.; Montgomery,
New Orleans, Jackson, Cleveland,
Detroit and Buffalo. His second
tour, beginning April 8, will include
Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Louis,
Kansas City, Omaha and Oklahoma
City. The arrangements have been
made by the American Association
for International Conciliation.
Dr. Mabie spent the summer of
1913 in Japan lecturing in the universities on "American Ideals,Character and Life." His object was to
interpret America to the Japanese,
Just as, during the previous year,
Dr. Nitobe had interpreted Japan
to Americans. Dr.Mabie was upusually well received and the lectures
were reported to be tremendous
successes. The Imperial University
of Tokyo found it impossible to
meet satisfactorily the demands for
tickets of admission to his lectures.
Tributes to his popularity were
given by the Emperor, the President of the House of Peers, the
Mayor of Tokyo and others.
More than this, it has often been
said that Dr. Mabie rendered conspicuous services in the interest of
good mutual_ understanding between
the United States and Japan. Most
of his eighty lectures were given to
students, who, in that country, are
a most important factor in molding
public opinion. His elucidations of
American institutions and character
Were published widely in Japan.
His accounts of Japanese life, customs and ideals should be no less
interesting and valuable to Americans.

SENIORS WIN INTERCLASS DEBATE
Victorious Over Juniors in Annual Contest—Monroe Doctrine the Issue.
Tingley Best Soph Orator.

Nineteen fourteen won the annual
interclass debate Friday night in
McCoy Hall. The class won from
the seniors of last year, and the
victory last week gives it the honor
of being the first class in many
years to win two successive debates.
The senior team, composed of
Malcolm Lauchheimer, •Steuart D.
White, Carl J. Weber, "Alec" Barton, alternate, and Albert L. Hammond, adviser, argued the negative
of "Resolved, That the Political
Interests of the United States Demand the Abandonment of the
Monroe Doctrine."
President-emeritus Remsen, Rev.
Dr. Charles Fiske and Joseph T.
Singewald, the judges of debate,
were unanimous in their decision
favoring the seniors. The junior
affirmative team consisted of Joseph
T. Bartlett, Jr., Millard Eiseman,
C. Sewell Weech, Avra Warren,
alternate, and F. Courtney Tarr,
adviser. Dr. John C. French presided.
From the standpoint of subject
matter, neither team gave evidences
of having delved deeply into the
rich fields of opinion available on
such an issue as the Monroe Doctrine. The seniors argued for continuance of the policy because, they
said, it was "necessary." The
juniors said it was "unnecessary,"
and so the debate went on. It developed, however, that the reasons
backing the senior claim were somewhat more clearly defined, and their
side of the question was more easily
defended because of the fact that
dramatic opposition to the Monroe
Doctrine is not possible, and the
decision properly went to '14.
The most finished presentation
during the debate was made by
"Joe" Bartlett, the first speaker for
the junior team. Carl Weber was
the most convincing of the seniors.
Thomas J. Tingley won the
Adams Medal for sophomore public speaking. He recited Robert
Ingersoll's dramatic nomination of
James G. Blaine for the Presidency,
which was the oratorical feature of
the Republican National Convention of 1876. The other speakers
were Samuel L. Leitheiser and L.
Clarence Cohn. The judges of the
contest were Prof. John H. Latane
and Wilfred P. Mustard and Dr.
David E. Wegelein.
Musical numbers were furnished
by the Instrumental Club, and four
picked "artists" from the Glee Club.

Glee and Instrumental Clubs Sing and
Play for Sick—Are Well Received.
Many Regular Men Absent.

"Cigar King" Finished With an Average
of .818—Melamet and Nachlas
Were Second and Third.

The combined Musical Clubs
gave a concert at the Phipps Cl:nic
on Tuesday, but there was a wholesale absence of singers and players,
making the affair somewhat disappointing to those who had journeyed over to Broadway to entertain the sick. The clubs, however,
were very well received and frequent encores were called for.
The Glee Club was unfortunately
unbalanced. There were plenty of
bass singers, but only one first and
two second tenors. The deepthroated men were thus compelled
to work the "soft pedal," and the
effect was said to be rather pleasing.
Some important- changes will
probably be made in the plan of
the schedule next year. Instead of
giving the more important concerts
and making all the trips in the early
part of the season and allowing the
organization to fall to pieces toward
the end of the season, the less important concerts will most likely be
arranged for the fall next year and
the heavier work done after Christmas. In this way it is hoped that
the spirit and enthusiasm will keep
up until the last concert has been
given.

Four women are among the six
students who stand highest in the
graduating class of the Hopkins
Medical School, according to Dr.
Franklin P. Mall, professor of
anatomy, who made the statement
to refute a charge that the feminist
movement was "biological bosh."
Prof. William T. Sedgwick of the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in a published article, said
recently that "biological bosh" was
the only term applicable to the action of women in forcing themselves to the front in every line of
endeavor. The article aroused the
ire of suffragists and also the interest of Dr. Mill.
Dr. Mall wrote a letter to Professor Sedgwick, in which he told
of the fine work of the women students in the fourth-year class of
the Medical- School. Everyone is
now interested to know just who
these women leaders are, but Dr.
J. Whitridge Williams, dean of the
school, is unwilling to give the
names at the present time. "To do
so," he said, "would not be proper,
since the averages of the students
will not be finally determined until
June, and it is possible that those
who stand at the head now may fall
back in their averages before Commencement Day."
The observation of Dr. Mall is
all the more interesting, inasmuch
as there are eleven women in the
class and eighty men.
Dr. Williams did say, however,
that five of the eleven women in the
fourth-year class were in the first
third of the class and in line for the
appointments to interneships in the
Hopkins Hospital. Two of these
young women are Baltimoreans.
They are Miss Alma Rothholz and
Miss Mabel Belt. Both were
graduated in the Class of 'o6 of the
Western High School. Miss Belt
subsequently took her bachelor's degree from Goucher College and
Miss Rothholz from Smith.

A New Rule for Freshmen.
An alumnus now holding a position with one of the large corporation in this city, in a letter to THE
NEWS - LETTER, proposes, among
other rules, that freshmen attendance at all organization meetings
of the University's activities, be
made compulsory. The suggestion
appeals at once, because of its
soundness and necessity.
It comes, too, just at a time when
the Student Council is formulating
a "Code of Freshman Regulations,"
and THE NEws - LETTER believes
that it should be made into a rule.
The men at the helm of the University's activities know how trying
it is to persuade first-year men to
become interested in some one of
the activities. To get a large attendance at the organization meetings requires a personal canvass;
and then, frequently, the results are
disappointing. Such a state of affairs should not exist. It is not
right that the leaders should "drum
up trade" among freshmen. The
new men should be made to realize
at the outset that they are not only
wanted, but urged to show an active
interest in the affairs of the college.
They will not realize this, however, unless it is brought before
them emphatically or even forcibly.
This, obviously, is not the duty of
the leaders of the specific activity;
it is the duty of the Student Council.
Then, again, a large freshman interest is necessary to maintain the
traditions of the University—espe-

cially is this true at this era of expansion. If the University is to
grow, its activities should become

IN FAVOR OF "BILLY" SUNDAY
Hopkins Ministers Almost Unanimous in
Wish to Get "Vaudeville Evangelist" for Baltimore Campaign.

Among the students in the University are a half dozen of ministers
who are taking an active part in the
discussion over the advisability of
securing "Billy" Sunday, the evangelist, for a Baltimore revival.
One of them who had a knife and
fork in the Emerson Lunch when
the subject was first discussed by
the Ministerial Union, confided the
following to a reporter for THE
NEws - LETTER during a physics
quizz:
"You won't tell anyone or make
fun of me, will you ?"
"Oh, no; of course not."
"Very well, then. I do certainly
want Mr. Sunday to come here. I
believe in muscularity, as you well
know, and I am very anxious to let
him get a chance at the Baltimore
sinners."
The following deposition is the
only one of dissent:
"I am opposed to going to the
theatre. They say Mr. Sunday is a
vaudeville performer, so I don't
think he'll fit in with my policies.
See!"

Yale's Football Trouble.

Yales real football trouble has
been oddly pointed out by Captain
Talbott's recent plea that the
coaches be barred from the sidelines and the quarterback be allowed
to run his game the way he wants.
Among the great colleges he stands
almost alone.
The answer to his attitude and to
the Yale football defeats is that
Yale has received to much coaching. In the West it has always
looked as though the multiplicity of
coaches at Yale should bring great
results. As a matter of fact, it has
brought ruin.
Last season there were six different offensive coaches, each with
his own theory of play. Shevlin
was perhaps the most prominent.
He boasts a distinct following that
believes in him utterly, but the
others were not far behind. As a
result, Yale was taught six different
theories of play and naturally could
not work any of them. In the Colgate game, where Yale suffered defeat, the eleven, bewildered by varying instructions, quit in despair. If
the quarterback had been left alone,
he might have saved the day by deciding for himself definitely on
something. Hence Yale wants him
left alone.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 16, 1914.

NEW LACROSSE MEN PROMISING
A Galaxy of Former City College Players
and Raw Material Pleases Coaches.
Outdoor Practice This Week.

With the first game of the season
less than two weeks off, and the
first outdoor practice to take place
in a few days, the lacrosse squad is
just entering upon the hardest work
of the season.
As has been the custom for a
number of years, the alumni twelve
will be met in the first game, which
is scheduled for March 28. Coach
Raney Wolfe, assistant coaches Eddie Hulburt and Bob Lowndes, the
Schmeisser brothers and many other
former stars will be in the line-up
for the alumni.
The squad finished its indoor practice last week and on Wednesday.
Captain "Butts" Sutton will have all
the candidates for the team report
at Homewood for the first line-up
practice of the season.
The coaches are pleased with the
improvement made by the new players. Four of them—Kaiser, Brooks,
Baxley and Fulton — are fighting
for positions on the defense, and a.1
will be given trials in the early
games before any definite selections
are made. Stuart and Bartlett are
improving as candidates for the
goal position. On the attack, Prince
and Nelson have, by hard work,
forged rapidly to the front and will
probably be given a chance to make
good in one or more of the games.
Paul Sutton and Frank will make
good "bench-warming candidates,"
ready to be used in any exigency.
Leibensperger, gridiron star, who
was a member of the lacrosse squad
last year, will start practice on
Wednesday. He has been excused
from cage practices because of his
inability to see the ball there.
All efforts from now on will be
devoted to the development of
team-work, which, so far, is lacking. "As a collection of about thirty
individual lacrosse players, some
good and some fair, the squad looks
excellent; but as a lacrosse team,
thus far, there is none," is the
opinion of an old player who
watched practice last week.
W. and L. Solves High Cost of Living.

Washington and Lee's athletes
have discovered a new way to get
the better of Mr. High Cost of Living. Good board here is quoted at
about"six dollars a week, but students who are taken ill can be
housed at the hospital indefinitely
for two dollars—not a week, but
per annum.
The mumps have been floating
around Lexington and they first got
to Caminero, one of the basketballers, who had to go to the hospital and stay there for some time.
He was later joined by Jim Somerville, the discus thrower; Kit Carson, the pitcher, and several other
athletes. Richard W. Fowlkes, assistant manager of the basketball
team, is getting pneumonia in order
to qualify for admittance to the infirmary.

The regular lectures of Dr.
Charles Francis Adams'course came
to an end last Thursday, when the
noted Bostonian talked of the effect
which Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation had upon the English policy during the Civil War.
The feeling in England up to
the time of the proclamation had
been decidedly in the South's favor,
and the British Ministry was on the
point of recognizing the Confederacy as a nation. However, the element of slavery, which was brought
forward to a prominent position by
Lincoln's act, turned the tide against
the South. While slavery was not
a great factor in causing the struggle, and while the North was not
fighting with an eye to stamping it
out, the impression got abroad in
England that this was the case, and
the lower classes especially took a
firm stand against the recognition
of the Southern States.
Dr. Welch announced before the
lecture that Dr. Adams would give
two extra talks, on Thursdays,
March 19 and 26, upon his "Opinions and Theories of the Experiences, Career and Character of Gen.
Robert E. Lee." Lee is said to be
a favorite character of Dr. Adams.
His studies of.the great Virginian
are ranked among the most valuable contributions to his biography.

John Dorsey Gets His "H.M."

KARL J. STEINMUELLER,
Box 558, J. H. U.

At the regular monthly meeting
of the Athletic Board Tuesday, Page
Hunter was reappointed as assistant
football coach, and will work with
Coach Cates again next fall. Manager John Dorsey was finally awarded his "H. M." for services as manager of the 1913 football team.
The schedules arranged by managers of spring sports and football
were ratified.
